test_cases.name: Basic concept extraction
test_cases.input_notes: Machine learning is a subset of artificial intelligence that enables systems to learn from data. Supervised learning uses labeled data, while unsupervised learning finds patterns in unlabeled data.

test_cases.name: Technical definitions
test_cases.input_notes: A neural network consists of layers of interconnected nodes. Each node applies an activation function to its inputs. Backpropagation is used to train the network by computing gradients.

test_cases.name: Multi-concept coverage
test_cases.input_notes: Overfitting occurs when a model memorizes training data. Regularization techniques like L1 and L2 help prevent this. Cross-validation assesses model performance on different data subsets.

test_cases.name: Process-based questions
test_cases.input_notes: The scientific method involves: 1) Observation, 2) Hypothesis formation, 3) Experimentation, 4) Analysis, 5) Conclusion. Each step builds on the previous one.

test_cases.name: Comparison questions
test_cases.input_notes: SQL databases are structured and use tables with predefined schemas. NoSQL databases are flexible and handle unstructured data. SQL is best for complex queries, NoSQL for scalability.

test_cases.name: Historical context
test_cases.input_notes: The Internet was created in the 1960s as ARPANET. TCP/IP protocols were standardized in 1983. The World Wide Web was invented by Tim Berners-Lee in 1989.

test_cases.name: Mathematical concepts
test_cases.input_notes: The derivative measures the rate of change of a function. Integration finds the area under a curve. The fundamental theorem of calculus connects these two operations.

test_cases.name: Biological systems
test_cases.input_notes: Photosynthesis converts light energy into chemical energy in plants. It occurs in chloroplasts and produces glucose and oxygen from CO2 and water.

test_cases.name: Programming paradigms
test_cases.input_notes: Object-oriented programming organizes code into objects with properties and methods. Functional programming treats computation as evaluation of mathematical functions and avoids state changes.

test_cases.name: Economic principles
test_cases.input_notes: Supply and demand determine market prices. When demand increases and supply stays constant, prices rise. Equilibrium is reached when supply equals demand.

test_cases.name: Chemical reactions
test_cases.input_notes: In a synthesis reaction, two or more substances combine to form a new compound. Decomposition reactions break compounds into simpler substances. These are opposite processes.

test_cases.name: Data structures
test_cases.input_notes: Arrays store elements in contiguous memory. Linked lists use nodes with pointers. Arrays offer O(1) access but O(n) insertion. Linked lists have O(n) access but O(1) insertion at head.

test_cases.name: Literary devices
test_cases.input_notes: Metaphor compares two things without using 'like' or 'as'. Simile uses 'like' or 'as' for comparison. Personification gives human qualities to non-human things.

test_cases.name: Physics laws
test_cases.input_notes: Newton's First Law: An object at rest stays at rest unless acted upon by force. Second Law: F=ma relates force, mass, and acceleration. Third Law: Every action has an equal and opposite reaction.

test_cases.name: Psychology concepts
test_cases.input_notes: Classical conditioning pairs a neutral stimulus with an unconditioned stimulus. Operant conditioning uses rewards and punishments to shape behavior. Both are forms of learning.

test_cases.name: Climate science
test_cases.input_notes: The greenhouse effect traps heat in Earth's atmosphere. CO2 and methane are major greenhouse gases. Rising temperatures cause ice melting and sea level rise.
